layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in three lines at the top of the face, justified to the right, reading horizontally. The stone is also inscribed with an Ogham inscription on the right edge of the Roman-letter inscribed face beginning about halfway to the top of the stone continuing over the top, reading vertically upwards. The Welsh Corpus notes that the combination of a horizontal roman-letter inscription with ogam is unusual but is paralleled on Clocaenog 1 (D1), Castell Dwyran 1 (CM3) and Nevern 2 (P71). The placement of the ogam inscription on the right angle...is also more unusual that the left but is paralleled in the north on Llanfaelog (AN13)...the positioning of the roman-letter inscription towards the right angle of the stone where the ogam is located is surely intentional since it signals a relationship between the two (Edwards 2013, 272).

handDesc.handNote: According to Edwards (2013, 270-1), the ogham inscription is pocked, incised with a punch. The Roman-letter inscription is set out unevenly...in capitals with miniscule S...R has an open loop and the diagonal is seperate; the diagonals of V in line 1 do not meet and touch the horizontal bar of the T in line 2; the tail of the S likewise touches the top of the I below; the diagonal of the N in line 2 veers slightly towards the horizontal (Edwards 2013, 270-1).

history.provenance: First found 1901 when removed to avoid obstructing a gateway approximately 300m north-north-east of Pen Llystyn Roman fort. Ogham was discovered 1903 when it was moved and set the right way up. Locally derived stone, described as dolerite microgabbro with a typical thick weathering crust and a homogenous texture (Edwards 2013, 270).
Set into the stone wall on the south side of the farmyard west of the farmhouse (SH 4821 4553).

div.p: The Roman-letter inscription is in the 'X son of Y' formula. The first name in the inscription,Icorix appears to have both British and Celtic influence while Potentinus is Latin and use of this is paralleled elsewhere in Britain and Ireland (Edwards 2013, 272-3). On the context of the stone, the Welsh Corpus notes the presence of a Roman auxiliary fort at Pen Llystyn and argues that the stone relates to continuing activity in the area of the fort, which would have remained a prominent landmark, in the post-Roman period (Edwards 2013, 271-2).

The Ogham inscription on the stone corresponds to the Roman-letter inscription, a thing which is also reflected in their placement in relation to each other. The spelling of ICORIGAS in the Ogham inscription suggests British influence. The Welsh Corpus argues that if the name is British, the ogam presumably uses C rather than G either following the roman lettering or following the Irish cognate...the name has no known descendants in later Welsh or Irish (Edwards 2013, 272-3).
